title: Aftersun
summary: Sophie reflects on the shared joy and private melancholy of a holiday she took with her father twenty years earlier. Memories real and imagined fill the gaps between miniDV footage as she tries to reconcile the father she knew with the man she didn’t.
caption: A tender and introspective exploration of a father-daughter relationship through the lens of memory.
analysis: Aftersun is a poignant and deeply moving film that delves into the complexities of memory and the passage of time. Through the delicate interplay of present-day reflections and past experiences, the film beautifully captures the fleeting moments of joy and sorrow that define our relationships. The narrative structure, interwoven with miniDV footage, adds a layer of authenticity and nostalgia, emphasizing the subjective nature of memory. Charlotte Wells' direction, combined with Paul Mescal's and Frankie Corio's heartfelt performances, brings a raw and emotional depth to the story, making it a profound meditation on the bittersweet nature of growing up and letting go.
quote: When you were 11, what did you think you would be doing now?
